column45: Assumptions

The company's scrap recycling emissions intensity is assumed to remain unchanged from 2017 onward. The company's ratio of alumina to primary aluminium production is assumed to remain unchanged from 2017 onward.

TPI has not made any further assumptions in order to project this company’s Carbon Performance. The company has not set targets to reduce its emissions intensity. 
Despite Alumina itself not setting targets, AWAC, of which Alumina owns 40%, does have targets in place.
The company's activities lie outside the scope of TPI's Carbon Performance assessment in this sector, hence the company is not assessed.
The company has not disclosed sufficient data on current emissions, or any quantitative targets to reduce its emissions, which TPI can use to estimate future Carbon Performance.
The company's activities lie outside the scope of TPI's Carbon Performance assessment in this sector, hence the company is not assessed.

TPI has not made any further assumptions in order to project this company’s Carbon Performance.
Norsk Hydro has a net zero emissions target for 2020. TPI does not consider this target, as it includes avoided emissions.
The company has not disclosed sufficient data on current emissions, or any quantitative targets to reduce its emissions, which TPI can use to estimate future Carbon Performance.

Emissions from bauxite mining were assumed to be negligibly small compared to alumina refining and aluminium smelting emissions. All of the company's produced alumina is assumed to be smelted into aluminium by the company itself.
Rio Tinto discloses emissions targets, but these refer to the company as a whole and not to aluminium activities specifically.

The company has not disclosed sufficient data on current emissions, or any quantitative targets to reduce its emissions, which TPI can use to estimate future Carbon Performance.
South32 discloses emissions data as well as targets, but these refer to the company as a whole and not to aluminium activities specifcially.
The company's activities lie outside the scope of TPI's Carbon Performance assessment in this sector, hence the company is not assessed.
The company's ratio of alumina to primary aluminium production is assumed to remain unchanged from 2017 onward.

CRH has set targets to reduce its emissions intensity. For this company, TPI has assumed that:
● The emissions intensity of the operations that are not covered by the target remains constant between the date it was last observed and the target year.

UltraTech Cement has set targets to reduce its emissions intensity. For this company, TPI has assumed that:

AGL Energy has not disclosed a quantitative target to reduce its emissions which TPI can use to estimate future carbon performance.

Alliant Energy has set a target to reduce its absolute emissions.TPI has adjusted this target by assuming that future electricity generation grows at the same rate as the IEA's "Gross electricity generation" projections for the region in which the company operates using the ETP (2017) Reference Technology Scenario.

Ameren has set a target to reduce its absolute emissions.TPI has adjusted this target by assuming that future electricity generation grows at the same rate as the IEA's "Gross electricity generation" projections for the region in which the company operates using the ETP (2017) Reference Technology Scenario.

American Electric Power has set a target to reduce its absolute emissions.TPI has adjusted this target by assuming that future electricity generation grows at the same rate as the IEA's "Gross electricity generation" projections for the region in which the company operates using the ETP (2017) Reference Technology Scenario. TPI also assumes that: 
● Emissions from electricity production will reduce in-line with a broader emissions target
The company’s activities lie outside the scope of TPI’s Carbon Performance assessment of this sector, hence the company is not assessed.

Chubu Electric Power has set a target to reduce its emissions intensity. TPI has adjusted this target by assuming that:
● The historic ratio of electricity sold to electricity produced applies in the future

TPI also assumes that:

Fortis has set a target to reduce its absolute emissions.TPI has adjusted this target by assuming that future electricity generation grows at the same rate as the IEA's "Gross electricity generation" projections for the region in which the company operates using the ETP (2017) Reference Technology Scenario. TPI also assumes that: 
● Emissions from electricity production will reduce in-line with a broader emissions target 
● Emissions revelent to the TPI that are not covered by the target are assumed to be unchanged from the target base year in absolute or intensity terms
● The historic ratio of emissions from electricity production to the emission metric used in the target applies in the future

The company discloses an emissions intensity using an activity measure and/or emissions figure that is inconsistent with TPI’s methodology for this sector. To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that: The company’s externally sold energy products grow according to the regional or global primary energy supply growth rate projected in the IEA’s Energy Technology Perspectives model ‘Reference Technology’ scenario. The company’s target covers a subset of Scope 1, 2 and 3 (use of sold products) emissions. The emissions intensities of all emissions not covered by the target are assumed to remain constant from the level of the latest disclosure.

The company discloses separate emissions intensities for each type of its owned bulker vessels. TPI estimates the carbon intensity across all owned vessels, by weighting individual vessel intensities by their share of the total Dead Weight Tonnage of the company's owned fleet. It is assumed that the reported carbon intensities for 2018 are based on the same units of emissions (grams) as the 2017 figures. The company provides insufficient data on its quantitative targets to allow TPI to estimate future Carbon Performance.
